userreviews.userReview: Our Review, by LITERAL ADDICTION's Pack Alpha - Chelle:*Copy gifted in exchange for an honest reviewBook #2 of the OMEGA DAYS series picks up where book #1 left off in a ridiculous cliff-hanger that had me both ranting at the author and clamoring for Ship of the Dead. After all ending up in the same place for the most part, all of our favorites (well MY favorites anyway) return in book #2, this time searching for a way to survive in what is exponentially becoming the end of days. As the unexplained and utterly confusing virus waves through the country decimating city after city, our ragtag group of survivors decide that if they're able to win a Navy warship, they just might make it. Like a small floating city, it has everything they need - provisions, electricity, a hospital, etc. The only problem, like everything else, it's overrun by the dead, and they'll need to make sacrifices and fight like hell in order to survive.Slightly more zombie action driven than Omega Days (book #1) and more centrally storyline motivated (without constant shifts of POV between the different groups), there is tons of fabulously horrific gore, plenty of edge of your seat breath-holding moments, oodles of tragedy, action, suspense, and my favorite... the probing of the human psyche, which proves - unfortunately - that mankind may just be the worst monsters out there, especially when placed in a situation where morals are questionable, desperation abounds, and minds are easily lost. I really enjoyed book #1 of the series, but Ship of the Dead drew me in even deeper, establishing even stronger bonds with some of the remaining cast and desperately making me want to know what happens next in Drifters (book #3 coming in January). I know there have been mixed reviews with this series, but I really enjoy them, and I would totally recommend them for fans of zombie fiction. If you don't shy away from gore, utterly deplorable antagonists, and the darker side of reality, than take a chance with John L. Campbell and the OMEGA DAYS series. While not The Walking Dead, the books have a bit of that feel, and if you like the psychological side of TWD, I really do think you'll enjoy these books. Not everyone will agree with me, but take a chance and see for yourselves... :)
RTC, but just as good as the first one. Although Campbell's style is so predictable by the end of the second book that you know when someone is going to live or die.

I attended Book-Con 2014 in NYC in May. I met John Campbell at one of the booths and he was giving awaythe fuirst novel in this series, Omega Days. The only problem was that his shipment had not arrived in time so he took peoples names and addresses and said he would send them out when he got the books. I came home and as the weeks went it slipped my mind. The book finally arrived and was even a signed copy. Call me simple, but that really impressed me. A few weeks went by and I finally got around to picking it up and reading it. I loved it and couldn't wait for the next one to come out. Solast week I'm standing at the library in the new book section when this book pops out. I totally fan girled out right in the library. I made enough rackett that people came around the stacks to see what was making all the noise. I looked really dorky, but screw it. Igrabbed it and brought it home and pretty much read it from front to cover all in one shot. Around 3 am is when I finished. It was so worth the lack of sleep. Once again, John L. Campbell produced a spectacular 2nd book in this series. The book is full of zombie goodness. The survivers from the first book find the USS Nimitz (An aircraft carrier) and proceed to rid the ship of the undead and take it for their own. The undead are really not the scariest issues they have to deal with. A few of their own people have designs on other things than just surviving. I don't want to give away any more info, just know that if you love a good zombie series than I recommend picking this up. The next installment is due out in January 2015. I will be patiently waiting.

I think every cliche way to kill the myriad disposable characters was used, twice. I honestly lost any investment in any character and could not possibly care less if they all just die. Definitely won’t be tormenting myself with the rest of the series.
At first, I thought this book was a rip-off. It repeated parts of the first book. Once past that, it turned into a page turning thrill ride. I look to reading the other books in the series.

This review is void of any major spoilers.John L. Campbell is a great author. The setting of this story takes place on an aircraft carrier the USS NIMITZ and based on how elaborate and detailed he got with the setting you can tell he really did his research for this one. Throughout the story there were zero, and I mean no typographical or grammatical errors of any kind. What Campbell excelled at in the previous book was character development where he seamlessly flows from one individual narrative to the next always keeping you intrigued by the morbid and suspenseful plot.The same characters that were introduced from the first book make a reappearance as well as a couple new ones. He ties up all of the loose ends from the cliff hanger of the prior book and injects some new perspectives of the world along with it. Fairly quickly you find out what life is like on the open sea, the whereabouts of Maxie, the outcome of Skye's heroic/foolish standoff at the belltower and how all the characters behave around one another now that their individual narratives all get tied together.Towards the beginning of the book Campbell uses a discussion amongst the survivors to lay down the "rules" of the infection which is just like in the TV series The Walking Dead, where bites guarantee death and reanimation but even if you die through other means you still come back a zombie. Also introduced in this book is something known as "the slow burn" which opens up a very interesting look at the inner workings of the virus itself.Overall I did enjoy this book and plan to continue reading the series. The characters have unique and original personalities and very fleshed out back stories. My personal favorite characters are Skye for her inner fortitude, Carney for being the most well rounded character and (although a minor character) Maya for her spunk. I won't say who but Campbell does kill off some of his major Point of View characters from the prior book and from mybperspective it is nice knowing that even the major characters are not guaranteed to be safe. I mentioned it earlier but the knowledge of the environment is a real strong quality of Campbell's. The garb of the zombies based on their locations, the layout of the ship, the geographical history of San Francisco itself, all of these are taken into consideration. And most importantly, while the zombies are the major threat in the series, this book introduces multiple human antagonists just to prove that even in this world some individuals are more dangerous when they are alive as opposed to being zombified.That being said there were a few things I didn't like so much in this installment of the series one of them being how Campbell tips his hand through blatantly obvious foreshadowing as to when a particular minor character is about to meet their demise. You really aren't surprised when a majority of the minor characters get killed off because Campbell points out their mistakes literally right before they get killed off. Another pitfall is the luck aspect. Something you expect the characters to struggle to overcome and the answer to their prayers gets dropped directly into their laps gets to be a puzzling aspect of the story. Lastly on the downside of Campbell's writing is how cliché and corny some of the verbal exchanges are and towards the end some of the relationships that evolve into romantic ones are absolutely cringeworthy. My biggest critique of Mr. Campbell is that he is a well-researched and skilled writer but he should leave out the sappiness in his writings. Especially when every romantic relationship feels identical to one another but with different character names.The people I would recommend this book to would be the zombie-fanatics, anyone who enjoys the revolving character perspective narrative or if you're like me and are most intrigued by the moral dilemmas the characters find themselves in.

So all our heroes & villains from the previous book meet up on the docks of San Francisco with a relentless horde of zombies after them. Time for some nautical zombie action! (See Dead Sea and Black Tide Rising, among others.) As usual in zombie books, people want to gravitate to the usual safe places--sea, the arctic, some godforsaken forest--just once I'd like to see someone take over a Costco and just live there for a decade or two, which seems like the safer option, but anyways...Some Spoilers I guess...Across their perilous stronghold in some warehouse next to one of most populated cities in America is a partially destroyed aircraft carrier, so it's time to fight their way through its darkened hull and make that be their safe haven. Naturally, things go wrong with this cunning plan for most of them, and cherry on top is bringing along the lunatic televangelist & meth head for this assault. One thing that gets me is why not send a 2-3 person scouting team to check out the ship first? Points to them for at least trying to lure some of the topside zombies off the carrier, but why not just open the doorway they go through and just make a ton of noise for hours? Lure as many zombies overboard as they can? And then go in? Why are the folks keeping watch in all zombie books/films so terrible at it? You think your senses would be honed with fear and it's not like the living dead have ninja stealth on their side. I guess it wouldn't be as suspenseful otherwise and the book is pretty action packed since the setting is a ship packed with thousands of undead, a rapist, and a madman chasing after armageddon. I immediately started the third one.

Ship of the Dead is the second book in John L. Campbell's Omega Days Series. As a fan of the first novel, I knew it would be difficult to top. However, Campbell creates a fantastic urban warfare setting with this followup. The suspense is nonstop and you will certainly find yourself holding your breath on more than one occasion. Ship of the Dead takes place on an infested aircraft carrier, the only option left for our survivors. As we watch the survivors attempt to take back this ship from the dead, we are just sitting on pins and needles for something awful to happen with every turn of the page. The characters in this novel return from Omega Days and we see who the true leaders are and are introduced to some vile personalities that many managed to hide in the first novel. This novel took on a darker tone and we experience the loss of some beloved characters. However, others step up and you find yourself rooting for some unlikely characters. John L. Campbell has a talent for writing thrilling urban horror scenes. Campbell is the perfect author for fans of The Walking Dead and other novels and comics at the top of their game in the zombie genre. He does not leave out the important fact that the dead are not the only threat in this hellish new world. The ending of Ship of the Dead is one that will leave you with your jaw on the floor and running for the next book! This is every zombie lovers ideal series!http://novelideareviews.blogspot.com/...

I thought the "Ship of Dead" by John Campbell was very entertaining and action packed. Most of the book takes place in San Francisco on a ship called the U.S.S. Nimitz where the characters are trying to find a way to control the ship and escape San Francisco. There are many problems the characters face throughout the book, like how the ship has thousands of zombies on it and the tasks they have to complete in order to start the ship. The author brings in more characters which adds more depth in the book by talking about each of the new characters backstories. Most of the story is about the characters trying to get the ship working again. I loved the page turning action and the books high intensity. Book one of Omega Days which I have already read was very good but I liked the "Ship of the Dead better" because of the intensity and action. I often got confused and forgetting about some characters in the first book because the author kept adding more and more people to the story. One thing I really like about this book is that the zombies and starting the ship aren't the only problems, its also the characters. Different characters throughout the book change and turn insane which also adds more depth and intensity into the book. I would recommend this book to mature readers and to people who love post-apocalyptic fiction. I would rate this book 10/10 stars.

The second book in John Campbell's "Omega Days" series picks up where the first novel left off, with the main characters reaching the San Francisco harbor, on the run from a deadly horde of zombies, and seeking a safe refuge. What they find is a promising sanctuary in the form of an aircraft carrier - the USS Nimitz (CVN-68) - that came to a halt about a mile from the coast after the zombie virus struck its crew. The only problem is that the carrier is infested with zombies that stand between the survivors and their amply supplied safe haven. Campbell continues to develop the wide array of characters he introduced in the first novel, while also bringing in a few important new ones. Most of the plot is taken up with the survivors' plan to capture the ship and eliminate the zombies lurking throughout it, an adventure Campbell depicts with considerable tension, keeping the reader engaged. And along the way some major scores are settled, as some of the major characters prove to be as much of a menace as the zombies. While Campbell provides enough background detail on the characters for this novel to stand alone, it really should be read in conjunction with the first novel (Omega Days) for maximum enjoyment.

ANOTHER 5 STAR RATING FOR JOHN L. CAMPBELL.This is definitely a 5 star rating as the stakes get higher than they've ever been for Father Xavier, Angie, Skye, Carney and their groups as they all come together for one final showdown and what they hope will be their last dealing with the living dead. They head for the USS NIMITZ, hoping they can clear it of the dead and have a safe harbor for their loved ones and friends, as it's just out in the bay, dead in the water, but roaming with thousands of the dead and no way around it, they have to clear it from the deepest crawlspace to the top of the Island. But little do they know they have someone even worse than the dead in their midst. John L. Campbell has done another amazing job with this story and this is one book you don't want to end. This is one series you don't want to put down.

This is the second book in the series, and it was even better than the first! All of the groups and individuals that were introduced in the first novel, Omega Days, have converged on Alameda, but the zombies are converging there, too. Their last hope will be to try and rid the stationary carrier Nimitz of zombies, but the convict and the crazed or possessed televangelist have their own agendas. This was a lot more exciting, with edge of your seat action than the last one, even, and at one point I thought to myself "oh, no!" It's definitely a sign of a good book when you're that caught up in it!

Great second installment. I really enjoyed Omega Days but the Ship of the Dead was even better. The action took off from the start and increased in tempo until the last half of the book was non-stop. While the book has its main characters there are plenty of characters who appeared to likely be characters that would be ongoing suddenly are picked off in the action without warning and then they are gone. The end is another cliff hanger to setup the upcoming third book which I can't wait to be released.

The second book in the California zombie series proves to be a good one. The survivors have come together on Alameda Naval Station and will have to weigh other options for survival as their position is in peril of being overrun. Perhaps that aircraft carrier that has run aground in the bay. The only problem is they will have to clear out the current 4,000 plus undead residents. So for folks looking for a zombie series with a lot of action I will say this one is heating up quite nicely.

Another great continuation in the series - though that star it lost is mainly due to Peter *says something nice* *thinks of devious, wicked thing! Because don't forget guys, he's bad!*But honestly, about halfway through that faded out and either stopped happening, or I was too caught up in the story to keep noticing.

Considering I just read "The Walking Dead: The Rise Of The Governor" and was disappointed, as it was co-written by a multi-millionaire tv screenplay writer of the most watched program on tv...this was MUCH better. Campbell's writing is incredibly well researched, smooth, plush character development, and more twists and turns and teasers than an old-time cliffhanger. I'd highly recommend it.

I would like to give it 4.5 stars but I can't. A good zombie book and a great continuation of the series. THERE IS A LOT OF ACTION< VIOLENCE AND ZOMBIE SLAUGHTER!!!! Plus, no spoilers, the ending is TOTAL cliff hanger. I have the 3rd in the series at home and I will definitely be starting that tomorrow at work. If you like zombies, guns and action, this the one of the best series I have read.

I bought this Ship of the Dead immediatly after the first in e-book form, though unusually expensive I was quick to read this one too. Most second books in a trilogy falter and repeat a lot of the first but Ship of the Dead swiftly get's into the action and adds even more to the story. Another fantastic read!

I liked the first book but the follow up I loved. This one was so much better I actually started to care about the people. It had a lot character deaths but the story telling was awesome. I can't wait for the third book.

I thoroughly enjoyed the second book of John L. Campbell's, even more so than the first book. The characters come together better in this one and the setting of the ship is wonderful, truly unnerving at times. Can't wait to read the next one to see if Angie finds her family!

Felt like I was in itCan't help but feel like I felt like I was in it. The fast paced frantic battles and chapters kept me going and pulled me deeper and deeper into the story. The author makes you really like some characters and utterly despise others. On to the next book!

I am never, ever getting on a boat again. Second in the series, filled with tense moments, mounting dread, and claustrophobia. Great zombie book.Ps. Didn't realize the third book "Drifters" isn't out until January 15, 2015. Bummer for the wait but I'll definitely read it on release.

Fabulous!!! I loved this fast paced, terrifying adventure. I liked how the book is written to tell you different stories and how many different adventures you go on as the reader. It is wonderfully crafted and keeps the reader riveted to the action.

While not as good as the first book, I would love to see a movie version of this book with the battle on the Nimitz filmed in the style of The Blair Witch Project.Another easy read...this story would likely make a good plot for a video game.

description: In the weeks following the Omega Virus outbreak, survivors form desperate clusters, uniting to defend against hordes of the walking dead. But they can only hide for so long…Father Xavier Church never wanted to be a leader. Nonetheless, he’s grown attached to his fellow survivors, and he won’t let anyone cause them harm—though he may be the one who inadvertently leads them to destruction…Ex-con Bill Carnes may crave freedom, but he still prefers sticking with the group rather than fleeing to Mexico with his former cellmate TC. Maybe he’s changing. Or maybe the look in TC’s eyes is more dangerous than the undead…EMT Rosa Escobedo gave up on hope after she watched the man she loved rise from the dead. But when a patient seems to start getting better, she can’t help but hope for a cure, even if it means risking her life…As the numbers of the dead swell, the living are running out of safe havens—especially when the biggest threats lie within their own ranks.
